This file defines, Squares, pieces, boards and related functions.

Types

BB = int64
Bitboard - 0. bit = a1, 1. bit = a2, 63. bit = h8 
Square = range[-1 .. 63]
Square - values: NO_SQUARE, A1, ..., H8 
Color = range[0 .. 1]
Color type - values: WHITE, BLACK 
Piece = range[-1 .. 8]
Piece type - values: NO_PIECE, PAWN, KNIGHT, BISHOP, ROOK, QUEEN, KING, KING_ROOK, UNDO_MOVE, NULL_MOVE 
Board = object
  colors*: array[2, BB]         ## BBs for white and black pieces
  pieces*: array[6, BB]         ## BBs for pawns, knights, bishops, rooks, queens, kings
  activeColor*: Color          ## active color
  canCastle*: array[2, array[2, bool]] ## castling rights for white, black; queen side, king side
  isCheck*: bool               ## is current player in check?
  enPassant*: Square           ## target Square for en_passant (0 denotes none or idk maybe extend to range to -1)
  move50*: int                 ## ply counter since irreversible move
Board type

WHITE: Color = 0
BLACK: Color = 1
NO_PIECE: Piece = -1
PAWN: Piece = 0
KNIGHT: Piece = 1
BISHOP: Piece = 2
ROOK: Piece = 3
QUEEN: Piece = 4
KING: Piece = 5
KING_ROOK: Piece = 6
UNDO_MOVE: Piece = 7
NULL_MOVE: Piece = 8
UNIVERSE: BB = 0xFFFFFFFF
Universe (full) bitboard 
EMPTY: BB = 0
Empty bitboard 
CHESS_STARTING_FEN = "rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 0"
FEN of starting chess position. This is equivalent to id2FEN(518) (except for castling rights, which are TODO).

Procs

proc FEN2board(FEN: string): Board {...}{.raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}
Loads a board from FEN format. 
proc cleanFEN(FEN: string): string {...}{.raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}
Cleans a FEN. That is, converts empty string to default chess starting FEN, and interprets numbers as chess 960 positions, where 960 indicates random position. 
proc showInBrowser(position: Board; comment: string) {...}{.raises: [IOError],
    tags: [WriteIOEffect].}
Writes the board representation to a HTML file. 
proc showInBrowser(position: Board) {...}{.raises: [IOError], tags: [WriteIOEffect].}
Writes the board representation to a HTML file using an empty comment string.

func `>>`(a: BB; b: Square): BB {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
func `<<`(a: BB; b: Square): BB {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
func white(board: Board): BB {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
func black(board: Board): BB {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
func occupied(board: Board): BB {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
func free(board: Board): BB {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
func `$`(piece: Piece): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Converts a piece in PAWN..KING to a single letter representation. 
func `$$`(bb: BB): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates ASCII version of the BB, for debugging purposes. I think that single $ doesn't work, it doesn't override $(int64). 
func parseSquare(s: string): Square {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Parses a string representation of a square. "-" (as is used in FEN) maps to NO_SQUARE. 
func `$`(sq: Square): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Returns a string representation of a square. NO_SQUARE maps to "-" (as is used in FEN). 
func determinePiece(board: Board; sq: Square): Piece {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines what piece is on the square. If the square is empty, NO_PIECE is returned. 
func determinePieceCapture(board: Board; sq: Square): Piece {...}{.inline, raises: [],
    tags: [].}
Determines what piece is being captured on square sq. That is if sq is en passant target, PAWN is returned. Furhermore, we assume that the piece is not king, so we can exit the loop one iteration earlier. 
func id960FEN(N: int): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Creates FEN starting position from its 960 id. 
func FEN(board: Board): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates a FEN representation of the board. 
func `==`(a, b: Board): bool {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Tests two boards for equivality. Compares most likeli different terms first. TODO compare hash first 
func `$`(board: Board): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates ASCII representation of a board (for debugging purposes. 
func debugBoard(board: Board): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates ASCII representation of the internal variables comprising the board (for debugging). 
func htmlRepr(board: Board; comment: string): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates a HTML page displaying the board provided. The page automatically refreshes itself so it can be used as realtime board display - for debugging and for playing too. Extra text comment can be appended below the board.
